title: SB 1.17.42 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 22-03-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 42nd verse of the 17th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and the speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam that will be discussed.

segments.key_quote: So Kali became gold standardized as Prabhupada says in one of the previous purports.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the story of Parikshit Maharaj meeting Kali Purusha and how Kali was punished and given shelter, ultimately associating with gold.

segments.key_quote: So then the damage done by Kali Purusha was set right was corrected and that is being described here in this particular verse that the lost legs of the personality of religion were re-established.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on how Parikshit Maharaj restored the lost legs of Dharma (austerity, cleanliness, mercy, and truthfulness) and improved the condition of the earth.

segments.key_quote: By itself, wealth or gold is not bad. The improper or proper utilization, that matters.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses Srila Prabhupada's explanation of the verse's relevance to modern times, emphasizing that Parikshit Maharaj cheated Kali by designating specific places and that gold can be used for good or bad.

segments.key_quote: Maharaj Parikshit, therefore, like his grandfather Arjuna, collected all illicit gold kept for the propensities of Kali and employed it for the purpose of and employed it in the Sankirtan Yajna as per the instruction of the Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Parikshit Maharaj, like Arjuna, used illicit gold for Sankirtan Yajna, which is the recommended Yajna for Kali Yuga.

segments.key_quote: Namely, 50% for the service of the Lord. Lord means the Supreme Lord Krishna. 25% for the family members. And 25% for personal necessities.
segments.summary: The speaker shares Prabhupada's recommendation for dividing excess wealth: 50% for Krishna's service, 25% for family, and 25% for personal needs.

segments.key_quote: Spending 50% of the service of the Lord or for propagation of spiritual knowledge in society by way of the Sankirtan Yagna is the maximum display of human mercy this is actually a necessity for the human beings in the human society
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of using wealth for Sankirtan Yajna as the greatest act of mercy, enabling people to achieve their human mission and return to Godhead.
